frame.name: Alternatives
frame.definition:
<def-root>There exist a number of different possible <fen>Situation</fen>s that may happen in the future. (In some cases, the <fen>Situation</fen> is concurrent or past, and only the knowledge of which has happened is in the future.) In most cases, there is an <fen>Agent</fen> involved who has to consider which of the possible <fen>Situation</fen>s will or should occur. A <fen>Salient_entity</fen> which is deeply involved in the <fen>Situation</fen> may also be mentioned.
<ex><fex name="Agent">You</fex> <ment>have</ment> <fex name="Number_of_possibilities">but two</fex> <t><fex name="Situation">choices</fex></t> <fex name="Salient_entity">for your daughter</fex> .</ex>
While all the members of this frame denote possible situations, in principle, this frame could be split into a number of subtypes on the following basis: <ex></ex>1. Future.n, and most uses of alternative.n and possibility.n all evoke nothing more than a simple possible situation (not necessarily an <fen>Situation</fen>) with no <fen>Agent</fen>; the remaining frames would inherit from this. <ex></ex>2. Use.n evokes different possible things that can be done with a <fen>Salient_entity</fen> (i.e., <fen>Purpose</fen>s) and thus uses the Using frame; in this frame, the target denotes the <fen>Purpose</fen> that can be achieved. <ex></ex>3. way.n evokes different events that can lead to an Outcome (not necessarily a <fen>Purpose</fen>); this frame should use the Means frame. In this frame, the target denotes the possible Means actions. <ex></ex>4. option.n, choice.n, and many instances of alternative.n and possibility.n, evoke possible <fen>Situation</fen>s that an implicit or explicit <fen>Agent</fen> can bring about at will. A <fen>Purpose</fen> that would be served by bringing these <fen>Situation</fen>s about may be mentioned. A <fen>Salient_entity</fen> related to the <fen>Purpose</fen> may occur in place of the <fen>Purpose</fen>.
</def-root>

FE.name: Situation
FE.definition:
<def-root>Something that may happen in the future, or at least whose factual status is unresolved. This is often tagged in a second FE layer and generally contains the target.
<ex><fex name="Agent">You</fex> have a <t>chance</t> <fex name="Situation">at life</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Agent
FE.definition:
<def-root>An individual involved in the <fen>Event</fen>.
"<fex name="Agent">You</fex> have a <t>choice</t>."</def-root>

FE.name: Number_of_possibilities
FE.definition: <def-root>The number of different future <fen>Event</fen>s under consideration. <ex>There are <fex name="Number_of_possibilities">two</fex> <t>possibilities</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Salient_entity
FE.definition:
<def-root>An entity intimately involved in the <fen>Event</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Agent">You</fex> have one <t>choice</t> to make <fex name="Salient_entity">for him</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Purpose
FE.definition: <def-root>The state-of-affairs that the <fen>Agent</fen> hopes to bring about which is associated with some of the possible <fen>Event</fen>s but not others. <ex>There 's only one <t>choice</t> <fex name="Purpose">to get what you want</fex> .</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: possibility.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a thing that is possible; the state or fact of being possible.

lexUnit.name: choice.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a possibility that one can select

lexUnit.name: alternative.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: one of two or more available possibilities.

lexUnit.name: option.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: something that will or can be chosen

lexUnit.name: future.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a possibility that may occur.
